DOC.HEADLINE: SPORTS COLUMN:A SCRIPT, OR WOODS ' ROAD TO RECOVERY?

TEXT.P: Tiger Woods' statement last week had the ring of the first step toward treatment of an addiction. One hopes he becomes less Tiger and more Eldrick.
The best thing I heard from Tiger Woods the other day was that he is not coming back anytime soon.
Until Friday, I was convinced that he would materialize at the Masters in April, assuring everybody he had beaten this thing and was ready to see some azaleas again. Fore!
This is good. Woods has more important things to do, like acquire an adult personality and find out why he got himself in this trouble.

Up to now, the Woods story has been depicted through the prism of the good old golf tour, titillating scandal, business sponsors and the news media swarm. There is another prism -- the attempted recovery of somebody who may now consider himself an addict.
The silliest thing I heard the other day was some people in a sports bar -- the great big ubiquitous national sports bar -- commenting that Woods sounded scripted, as if that was so bad.

Up to now, Woods has hidden behind his smug script as the biggest name in golf, or maybe even the biggest name in sports, deigning to make a few public remarks, cussing and glaring as he went about his work, like a petulant child, and then slipping around in the night.

His statement the other day sounded familiar. It was the script of somebody who has realized he may have wrecked his marriage, hurt people close to him, and now it is time to try to gain control over his life. Powerless. Woods seemed to be saying he was powerless.

If that is the script, Woods should keep reciting from it, even if the folks in blogland say he sounds robotic. His words sounded to me as if they were a step, the first of the 12 steps of addiction treatment: the admission of being powerless over addiction.

The script was straight from the collective wisdom of Alcoholics Anonymous and the other disciplines that give people a chance to start again. All too often, rehabilitation centers wind up as punch lines, sounding like some sort of Club Med with tissue boxes. But sometimes, treatment centers can scare the tiger right out of somebody.
Yes, we are all weary of public confessions from A-Rod and Mark McGwire, but Woods' was quite different because he was talking about an addiction, in this case sexual.
As part of those steps, Woods talked about how much he had hurt people close to him, how he hoped to rebuild things someday. He sounded scared and alone and unsure he would ever get it right again.
Good, I thought. Somebody got to him.

My respect for rehab centers stems from 1981 when I was working on a book with Bob Welch, a baseball player and a friend, who is an alcoholic. I was allowed to spend a week at the center he had attended -- as long as I participated. One of the best things I ever did.

As it happens, the center was the Meadows, in Wickenburg, Ariz., where Woods is rumored to have gone last weekend. They did not go easy on anybody at the Meadows.Ever since then, I have always been dubious about athletes, fresh out of treatment, who show up back in the clubhouse. Stinking thinking, they called it at the rehab center. Grandiosity. It's not enough to learn the mechanics of sobriety -- how not to put cocaine up the nose or beer down the throat. People need to get at the feelings behind the addiction, or else they never lose the flippancy, the anger, the insecurity. Dry drunks, they're called. I've seen a few out in public.

Woods' words the other day sounded familiar. He seemed to have been told that some people can never put their marriages back together or regain the jobs they lost. They have to get clean first, then take the first tentative steps out in the world.

He sounded like an outpatient who was going back for more work. Reportedly, he and his wife and their two children were flown somewhere over the weekend. At least he is not coming back to golf right now.

Tiger Woods has always struck me as a stunted individual who sneered at people and could afford expensive handlers to clean up behind him. His haughtiness seemed to spring from the money and entitlement of his sport.

Maybe it's time to stop being Tiger and start being Eldrick Woods. Not a marketing ploy like some basketball superstar changing his uniform number, but a statement: I'm growing up. I'm Eldrick now. It's a thought.

The other day, Woods sounded different, like a guy who had been scared. He doesn't really owe that much to the public or his sponsors or the golf tour. He mostly owes it to himself and his family and friends to get himself straight.
He could, however, send word to his caddie-enforcer, Steve Williams, that this is not the best time to be threatening the gallery over potential insults. Didn't Williams get the memo about humility?

Maybe Woods will come back later this year, or whenever, and remind us and himself that he is staying clean -- one day at a time. From his respectful mention of Buddhism the other day, it sounds as if he has a chance. Stay away, Eldrick. And whatever you do, stay scripted.
